evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context, as corroborated by multiple independent sources.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, including missed information exchanges and delayed responses.

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational parameters specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback procedures.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and consistently present during the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA flight on 12-25 in the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The statements from crew members accurately reflect the communication dynamics during the event.
No other unreported communication occurred that could have mitigated the breakdown.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit, effective communication and warnings were given and acknowledged during the pushback phase.
If the crew had clear, consistent procedures that were followed and documented for communication during pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly indicates a lack of communication and coordination among crew members during the pushback, as the tug instructor did not receive warnings from the wingman or headset operator (H8), the trainee driver did not speak up when the instructor passed the TRP (H10), and the headset operator assumed the instructor's actions without questioning (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent and consistency of communication breakdown; no detailed transcripts or recordings of communications are provided.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the phase
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft systems
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase; all evidence describes human actions and situational awareness during pushback.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal data, including missed information exchanges and delayed responses.

assumptions: The statements from crew members accurately reflect the communication events
No other unreported communication occurred that would contradict the breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordination among crew preventing or addressing the pushback issue
If the crew had actively warned or corrected each other about the TRP overrun

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence directly shows missed information exchanges and delayed or absent responses among crew members (H8, H10, H12), indicating communication/coordination breakdown consistent with the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the extent of communication attempts and whether some communication was effective but unreported

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

defeaters: If evidence showed a missing or unclear TRP marking or environmental factor affecting visibility or identification during the inspection.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates the presence or identification of an environmental or marking deficiency on the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and available in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records.

assumptions: The provided history items (H1-H13) constitute the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records
defeaters: If no formal record or documentation existed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records
If the deviation was only verbally reported but not documented

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The historical records (H1-H13) document the pushback event including the procedural deviation where the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier (H4), with detailed accounts from involved personnel and subsequent notifications (H6, H8). This confirms the procedural deviation is documented and available in the historical timeline prefinal records.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming the records are part of the official Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 historical timeline prefinal records, only historical evidence items provided

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with the key features and operational parameters specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback procedures.

defeaters: Evidence showing the procedural deviation was consistent with Boeing 737-8AS pushback procedures or operational parameters
Clear documentation or testimony that the pushback beyond the TRP was authorized or standard practice
Evidence that the TRP markings or operational parameters were misunderstood or incorrectly applied

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast fence (H4), indicating deviation from expected pushback limits. The TRP clearance is defined (H7), but the tug instructor's signaling method was insufficient and no warnings were given (H8). The trainee and headset operator assumed the instructor's actions were correct despite passing the TRP (H10, H12). The TRP was noted as small (H13). This suggests the procedural deviation did not align well with key features and operational parameters for the Boeing 737-8AS pushback procedures.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether the procedural deviation was intentional or due to misunderstanding; lack of explicit procedural documentation in evidence

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure fits the key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase.

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the hist_t3_prefinal phase
Reports or data indicating aircraft control issues independent of tug operation
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence in the provided history items indicates any mechanical or control failure of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_t3_prefinal phase; all evidence relates to tug driver actions and pushback procedure.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew is robust against alternative explanations or defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_t3_prefinal context, as corroborated by multiple independent sources.

assumptions: Statements from crew members are accurate and truthful
No other unreported communication occurred that could explain the breakdown
defeaters: Additional evidence showing effective communication or warnings prior to the collision
Contradictory testimony from other crew members or independent observers
Technical data indicating system or equipment failure rather than human communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple independent sources (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator) consistently describe communication and coordination issues, including lack of warnings and assumptions made, supporting robustness against alternative explanations (H8, H10, H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in the exact communication exchanges and possible unreported interactions

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, communication device records, and physical presence reports to confirm availability

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify maintenance and functionality reports of communication equipment and confirm no outages during the event

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communications
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical and incident reports to determine if any crew member was incapacitated or impaired

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is resistant to defeaters in the context of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: Mechanical/control failure would manifest as inability to stop or control the tug/aircraft despite human interventions
defeaters: Direct evidence showing mechanical/control failure was unaffected by human or procedural interventions
Evidence of mechanical failure independent of human error or communication lapses

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite signals and roles intended to prevent this (H4, H8, H12). This suggests mechanical/control failure was not clearly resistant to defeaters, as human factors and communication issues contributed. No direct evidence supports mechanical/control failure resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit evidence on mechanical/control failure resistance to defeaters; ambiguity whether failure was mechanical or procedural/human

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should correspond to the key features and criteria defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA in the hist_t3_prefinal inspection on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP described applies to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA at the time of the 12-25 prefinal inspection.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings or environment did not match Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA criteria or were inconsistent with the inspection date.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 directly describes the TRP location and clearance for the Boeing 737-800, matching key features and criteria for the aircraft 9H-QAA. H13 supports the marking size and environment context. Together, they confirm the environmental/marking deficiency corresponds to defined key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: limited detail on marking condition or changes over time; no explicit inspection report text.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or exceptions during the hist_t3_prefinal inspection of the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP marking is considered the environmental or marking deficiency referenced in the claim.
defeaters: If there was evidence of clear, unambiguous, and consistently used marking or signaling methods that were effective in all roles during pushback, or if personnel had direct and reliable visual confirmation of the TRP.

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence indicates that visual signals to stop were insufficient and that key personnel had limited or no direct visual confirmation of the TRP, suggesting the identification of the environmental or marking deficiency was not robust against exceptions (H8, H11, H13).
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the effectiveness and visibility of the TRP markings and signaling methods during the pushback.

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed any crew member was absent or unreachable during the operation
If communication devices were non-functional or crew were isolated

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple history items (H1, H3, H8, H11, H12, H13) confirm that crew members (tug instructor, trainee driver, headset operator, wingman) were physically present and reachable during the operation, supporting the claim directly.

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to all crew members

defeaters: Evidence showing crew members were unable to access communication devices or channels
Reports of device malfunctions or communication blackouts
Explicit statements that all crew members actively used communication devices effectively

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: While communication devices (interphone) were operational (H1), the lack of warnings or challenges from crew members about the pushback passing the TRP (H8, H10, H12) suggests that communication channels were accessible but not effectively used by all crew members.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence confirming all crew members had full access and operational use of communication devices; ambiguity in whether communication breakdown was due to device availability or human factors.

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft and surrounding environment for the presence and visibility of all required markings; absence or obscurity lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental conditions allow for clear visibility of markings
children_spec.test_procedure: Evaluate lighting, weather, and other environmental factors affecting visibility; poor conditions lower probability

children_spec.statement: Markings are maintained and not degraded or obscured
children_spec.test_procedure: Assess the condition of markings for wear, fading, or obstruction; degraded markings lower probability

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against common counterarguments and alternative explanations within the context of Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 pushback operations.

assumptions: The statements from involved personnel are accurate and complete
No other unreported interventions or warnings occurred during the pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed that the headset operator or wingman actively warned or attempted to correct the deviation
If the trainee driver had explicitly questioned or intervened during the deviation
If the TRP markings were clearly visible and unambiguous to all personnel

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H8, H10, H12, H13) shows that the procedural deviation was not effectively challenged by involved personnel, who trusted the instructor's actions despite the pushback passing the TRP and causing damage. The visual signals and communication methods were insufficient to prevent the deviation, indicating robustness against common counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of explicit counterarguments or alternative explanations documented in the evidence
